Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2008 08:25AM LizM wrote: One more thing.  Your oncologist should give you a copy of the pathology on your lymph node at your appt.  If he doesn't, ask for one.  I would definately ask about an MRI to locate the primary but they may already have that planned for your future anyway.  It is also common practice now to have an MRI of both breasts just to ensure there is nothing in the good breast that should be treated as well.  Important aspects of your pathology are the type, ductal or lobular, whether your are hormone receptor positive ER and or PR and whether it is her2 neu receptor positive or negative.  The biology of your tumor determines targeted therapy which will be used for treatment.

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2009 07:17AM LizM wrote: If I may I'd like to offer some advice.  Try not to dwell too much on PET and bone scans.  I am over 3 years out from a stage II diagnosis and have never had a PET or bone scan.  Just take it one step at a time.  All you know right now is that you have been diagnosed with breast ncer and it looks like it may be stage II due to size.  That alone is a lot to wrap your head around.  I would mention your pain to your doctors and they will let you know if they think scans are necessary.  Too much information in the beginning can be very frightening.  I spent the month from diagnosis to surgery reading every survivor story I could find and believe me there over 2 million breast cancer survivors living in the US and it is not hard to find stories.

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2008 07:35PM LizM wrote: Cebula, I had all of my treatment at Johns Hopkins.  Normally you see the breast surgeon first to determine the type of surgery, lumpectomy or mastectomy.  The only time you see a medical oncologist first is if your tumor is larger and neo-adjuvant chemo is recommended before surgery.  You intially asked about having your pathology slides read for a second opinion.  I agree that would not normally be done until after surgery.  The biopsy is only to determine if you have cancer.  The pathology after surgery is the most important.  If you want a 2d opinion before surgery at Hopkins you may have to wait a few weeks, but you can give them a call and see how long it will be to get an appointment.  Did you have an MRI of both breasts?  I ask that question because that is now standard practice at many major cancer centers before surgery to ensure there are not more tumors that are missed either in the same breast or other breast.  If you are comfortable with your breast surgeon and your type of surgery, you could send your pathology slides to Hopkins and consult with a medical oncologist to discuss treatment after your surgery.

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2008 12:52PM LizM wrote: I was in your situation almost 3 years ago when diagnosed at the age of 49.  I was premenopausal at diagnosis (stage IIb 2.1 cm 1+node).   After chemo I had my levels checked and I was in the postmenopausal range but my oncologist would not recommend an AI because he said he has seen women at my age who were put into menopause by chemo have their periods return up to 2 years after chemo.  He did not suggest I have my ovaries removed as he was fine with me taking Tamoxifen for a couple of years and then swtiching to an AI.  I on the other hand wanted to remove my ovaries to ensure I was postmenopausal and to take an AI.  I consulted with a gyn oncologist and she thought it was perfectly reasonable to remove my ovaries to treat my breast cancer.  Four weeks after radiation I had a laproscopic oophorectomy.  It was a very simple surgery and I only missed a few days of work.  Shortly after that I started on Arimidex.  It was funny because the next time I saw my oncologist he seemed please that I had the surgery and told me that I had chosen the most aggressive treatment.  I have never regretted my decision.

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2008 08:17AM LizM wrote: Hi Cupcake, So sorry you had to join us here but you have made a wise decision in coming  here for support.  We have all been through the fear and uncertanty you are going through now.  Because the breast cancer was found in the lymph node means they know it has spread that far.  You will likely have more tests to determine the stage and extent of disease.  It is not unusual for a mammogram and even ultrasound to miss cancer in the breast.  Are they planning a breast MRI to locate the primary tumor?  MRI's are often more effective at finding small tumors or lobular breast cancer which does not form a lump.  Having breast cancer in the nodes does mean you will have more aggressive treatment including chemo.  Treatment is normally based on extent of the disease or aggressiveness of the tumor not necessarily the size.  There are rare occasions where the primary tumor is not found but I don't think you are at that point yet as you will probably undergo more tests to find the primary.  In 2005 I was diagnosed with stage II breast cancer with one lymph node involved.  I had a bi-lateral mastectomy with reconstruction, chemo, radiation and am now on hormone therapy.  I was very aggressive with my treatment and so far (will be 3 years in Sep) I am doing fine.  Just take it one step at a time.  Try not to look to far into the future.  Come here often and ask questions.  The women here are very knowledgeable.  We have all been through this journey and there is nothing like talking to those who truly understand.

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2009 06:58AM LizM wrote: Having more than one tumor does not make your prognosis worse.  My ultrasound indicated I had multifocal tumors as well.  The ultrasound showed a 1.4 cm tumor and a 3 mm tumor.  My final pathology after surgery just mentioned one tumor 2.1 cm.  I also had very dense breasts and my mammograms were clear including the one the day they found my tumors by ultrasound.   I was also shocked that my tumor was as large since I had been very diligent with my mammograms but in reality 2 cm is NOT that large.  It is just the beginning of stage II.  By the time a tumor is large enough to be seen or felt it has probably been there for several years if not more.  A few more days or weeks is not going to make a difference in your prognosis so try not to panic which I know is easier said than done because I was in a panic mode from the time I was diagnosed until I had my surgery.

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2008 01:55PM LizM wrote: I am very happy with my treatment at Hopkins.  I had a bi-lateral with immediate reconstruction (tissue expanders/then implants) 3 years ago.  I also had chemo, rads and an oophorectomy at Hopkins.  I receive all my follow-up care there now.  I got in to see my breast surgeon 5 days after I was diagnosed.  I had my surgery 4 weeks after diagnosis, chemo 4 weeks after surgery, rads 5 weeks after chemo and my oophorectomy 4 weeks after rads.  My medical team is top notch.  The first two years after treatment I saw each one 4 months apart.  I now see my medical oncologist and breast surgeon 6 months apart.  One thing I really like about my medical team is that they support all of my decisions even if they were not necessarily what they recommended (rads and ooph for example).  My medical oncologist places a high importance on my peace of mind.  He even retested my tumor for her2 when I was nervous about the pathology showing an IHC of 2+ and fish neg.  I highly recommend Johns Hopkins.  I owe them my life.

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2011 03:59PM - edited Jan 24, 2011 04:01PM by LizM Barry, since you have DCIS in one breast and IDC in the other, I certainly understand why your surgeon is recommending bi-lateral with reconstruction.  It is not normally the biology of the cancer that dictates the type of surgery.  Just ask the many with DCIS (stage 0) who have had mastectomies.  You probably do have stage one grade one but you will not know that for sure until you have your surgery.  After my biopsy we thought my cancer was stage I and grade 1 but when I had my surgery it turned out to be grade 1 but was 2.1 cm and I had a positive lymph node, stage IIb.  I'm sure at some point  my cancer was stage 1 and grade 1 but we didn't find it then.  My recommendation is to have your surgery as soon as possible.  It is fine to wait 4 to 6 weeks to get opinions on types of surgeries, reconstruction and for scheduling but I would not wait until summer.   I had to wait 4 weeks to schedule my breast surgeon and plastic surgeon since I was having bi-lateral mastectomies with immediate reconstruction.  Good luck with your decision, I know that they are not easy.

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2008 05:28PM LizM wrote: Roxy, If I am correct you were stage II with a positive node and you had an oophorectomy.  There is absolutely no reason why you cannot take one of the aromatase inhibitors since you had your ovaries removed.  You ARE postmenopausal.  You know that with positive nodes you are a higher risk of recurrence.  Please talk to your doctor about putting you on either Femara, Arimidex or Aromasin.  I remember you saying that your oncologist wanted you to stay on Tamoxifen after your oophorectomy but I would insist they put you on one of the AI's or get a new oncologist.  You have many options for hormone therapy since you are now post menopausal.  I am being treated at Johns Hopkins and my oncologist did not blink an eye when he swtiched me to Arimidex after my oophorectomy.   You need to be on some type of hormone therapy.  Tamoxifen is not your only choice.

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2010 07:38AM - edited Aug 15, 2010 07:43AM by LizM Winterstorm,  According to my medical oncologist at Johns Hopkins, who is also a chair at ASCO, none of those tests are necessary when you are diagnosed with early stage breast cancer.  He feels scans are totally unnecessary unless there are symptoms and having those scans can cause undue stress for the patient.  I was diagnosed with stage II with one positive lymph node and have never had any scans and it will be five years this fall.  I have had numerous discussion with my oncologist on this topic and he feels very strongly.  He even wrote the guidance issued by ASCO to clinical oncologists which states no scans are necessary.  They don't even recommend blood tests after treatment - just follow-up consults with your oncologist and regular mammograms.  However, if you have symptoms, they will recommend scans to rule out mets.  My oncologist also told me that if the breast cancer has spread to other parts of the body, the success of treatment to keep the disease under control will not make a difference if you find out about it early on or after you have symptoms. I am comfortable with this,  I am very in tune with my body and if I have any pain or symptom out of the ordinary I wait for 2 to 3 weeks and if it doesn't go away, I contact my oncologist or family physician.

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2007 05:14PM LizM wrote: I can only tell you my story in hopes that may help you with your decisions.  I did not have cancer in both my breasts but did have chicken soup in my left breast.  My 2.1 cm tumor had insitu (DCIS/LCIS) and infiltrating mammary carcinoma with ductal and lobular features (IDC and ILC).  I opted for a bi-lateral mastectomy with immediate reconstruction (tissue expanders).  I had a laproscopic oophorectomy also but had that surgery after I completed chemotherapy and radiation.  I did not make the decision to remove my ovaries until later.  My bilateral/reconstruction surgery was 4 1/2 hrs.  My laproscopic ooph was less than an hour.  A hysterectomy is more involved and recovery is also longer.  Having a hysterectomy in addition to oophorectomy does not really add any value as far as your breast cancer.   Removing your ovaries which is the source of your estrogen production if you are premenopausal is an effective treatment against breast cancer (although most oncologists will not recommend it).  Adding hormonal therapy after the ooph also gives you added protection.  I had my oophorectomy done by a surgical gyn oncologist.  I suspect it is possible to have a bi-lateral/reconstruction and ooph at the same time.  I would ensure you are being treated at a major cancer hospital with breast surgeons and plastic surgeons who have done hundreds of bi-laterals with reconstruction and where they have experienced gyn oncologists.  Good luck with your decision and sorry you had to join this club.
Posts.Title: bilateral, oophorectomy, reconstruction - need your advice and experience - decisons to make and really scared my2girls Erica

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2007 05:29PM LizM wrote: One more issue.  I am assuming you already know that your breast cancer is estrogen and or progesterone positive as removing your ovaries is only effective for ER/PR ++ bc.  Another reason for the ooph is if you test positive for one of the bracs genes and have an increase risk of ovarian cancer.  I tested negative for both brac1 and 2 and still opted to remove my ovaries.
Posts.Title: bilateral, oophorectomy, reconstruction - need your advice and experience - decisons to make and really scared my2girls Erica

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2007 07:59AM LizM wrote: Hope, I had multi-focal disease with one main tumor and another tiny tumor in the same quadrant. My breast surgeon said he could try to get it all with a lumpectomy but I decided to just go for a mastectomy with immediate reconstruction. My breast surgeon had referred me to plastics before I made my decision so I kind of sensed that mastectomy was the way to go in my case. I then chose to remove the other breast prophylactically (sp) because of having dense breasts and also so that they would match. It is my understanding that lumpectomy plus radiation is just as good as mastectomy as far as distant recurrence and overall survival. However, having a lumpectomy does carry a slightly higher risk of local recurrence in the breast. Most surgeons and hospitals push breast conservation as opposed to mastectomy but there are still a lot of us who choose mastectomy for peace of mind. It's a very personal decision.

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2009 12:53AM LizM wrote: Hi Kendal, My name is Liz and I am a four year breast cancer survivor.  I also work as a volunteer at a major NCI designated cancer center helping out newly diagnosed women.  I just read your story and wanted to tell you how happy I am that you are getting some second opinions, preferably from a Breast Cancer surgical oncologist (not general surgeon) who has done many many breast cancer surgeries and is up on the latest treatments.  Please strongly consider having reconstruction and also consult with a breast cancer reconstructive surgeon.   It may take you a little longer to coordinate the schedules of both for surgery if you decide on reconstruction, but you have time.  Your breast cancer has taken years to grow to the size that it is now.  I had both of my breast removed with immediate reconstruction and have never regretted my decision.  Waking up from surgery with something there was very important to me and you are very young with many many years ahead of you.  I had tissue expanders and then implants because my breast were small and I was also thin so not a candidate to use my own tissue.  If you decide to go that route please send me a DM and I will be happy to share my story with you.  I also had chemo.  I was reading your pathology reports and your cancer seems to be fairly small and I believe I read the ultrasound of lymph nodes looked clear.  Of course they won't know anything for sure until after surgery.  Most breast cancer are grade 2 so that should not be cause for concern.   Most people DO NOT consult with their oncologist before surgery.  After you have the final pathology results from surgery, your breast surgeon will likely set you up for an appointment with your oncologist to go over the path results and discuss further treatment to keep the cancer from coming back.  I have heard nothing by good things about Sloan, Memorial and Kettering.  I was treated at Johns Hopkins and they DO NOT recommend scans before surgery for early stage breast cancer.  I am surprised that your doctor has recommended all those scans before surgery.  That is not the standard protocol for early stage which is what it looks like you have.  I know that you are at the scariest part of your journey when you don't know excactly what you are dealing with, just hang in there, you are going to be just fine.  Take Care,

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2009 10:50AM LizM wrote: Hi Maria, Yes I had chemo.  Full story is below: Diagnosed at age 49 (soon to be 53 now) and was premenopausal.  Path of biopsy indicated two tumors, one 1.4 cm and one 3 mm.  Surgeon indicated he could do a lumpectomy but I opted for bi-lateral mastectomy with reconstruction due to dense breast tissue.  Final pathology only indicated one tumor at 2.1 cm and one positive node.  In 2005, the oncotyDX test was not available for node positive so my positive node was my ticket to chemo. I had dose dense chemo (AC X 4 followed by Taxol X 4) and opted for radiation after mastectomy due to studies showing reduced risk of local recurrence when adding radiation with 1 to 3 positive nodes and rads oncologist wanted to radiated the auxilla as well.  Then I opted to remove my ovaries to ensure I could take an aromatase inhibitor since studies show them to be more effective at reducing risk of recurrence than Tamoxifen. (have been taking AI's since 2006 with very few problems)  Chemo put me in chemopause but no guarantees I would stay in menopause unless I surpressed ovaries and at age 50 didn't think I needed them anyway. I was very aggressive with my treatment as my oncologist reminds me when he see me but it gives me peace of mind to know I did everything I could to prevent a recurrence.  In my opinion, your first shot is your best shot.  I know how hard these decisions are to make but we have to do what is right for us.  I followed by gut through my treatment and my gut has served me well.  I do not regret any decisions I made with my treatment.

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2011 04:11PM - edited Jan 18, 2011 04:12PM by LizM Maxine,  sometimes you can get a feeling from your medical team which way they are leading you.  I had multi-focal disease and also DCIS and LCIS but all was in the same quadrant.  My breast surgeon (highly acclaimed and good at what he does) told me he could try to do a lumpectomy but when he scheduled me to see a plastic surgeon to discuss my opinion of mastectomy with immediate reconstruction, I kind of knew that was the direction they were leading me even though they told me it was my decision.  I did opt for the mastecomy (bi-lateral actually) with immediate reconstruction.  If you go with the lumpectomy, you need to be prepared that they may not get clean margins and may end up doing a mastectomy anyway.  It does happen, especially when there is more than one tumor and/or extensive DCIS.   As I said previously, this is not an easy decision to make.  My recommend is to go with your gut and what you think is right for you.

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2009 07:05PM LizM wrote: I was told by my a breast cancer expert that the surgical pathology report is the one they use and trumps the biopsy report.  I asked this because my biopsy had my tumor as grade 2 and my final pathology said it was grade 1.  I prefer the grade one and that is what I am going with.  I was told that the biopsy is just a tiny tissue sample and breast cancer is heterogeneous and can have faster growing areas but that the final pathologist looks at the entire tumor sample and gets a better look at the entire tumor thus the grade is more accurate.  Hope that helps.

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2007 04:43PM LizM wrote: Here's my story. Don't want to scare any of you but thought you might like to hear it. I was diagnosed in Oct 04 with ADH by stereotactic biopsy. Then had excisional biopsy and it came back ALH. I was being treated at Johns Hopkins. They went back and tested the specimen from the first biopsy again and it still came back ADH but there was no ADH only ALH in the larger specimen from the excisional biopsy. Due to this I was put on a six month screening program with mammogram (but no MRI). I did ask my breast surgeon if I could also have an ultrasound. Fast foward to Sep 05. Mammogram was clear but ultrasound found a suspicious mass. Biopsy came back as invasive ductal carcinoma. Opted for bi-lateral mastectomy. Final pathology was insitu and infiltrating mammary carcinoma with ductal and lobular features (IDLC). I have since had chemo, rads and am on Arimidex and so far so good. I am telling you this because I am one who had ADH and ALH and ended up with IDC and ILC all in the same breast. Also, the pathology on my prophylactic side came back as ALH so it probably would have developed into IDC and/or ILC down the road. Please ladies be diligent in your screening and I highly recommend having MRI's as part of your screening. My sister was also diagnosed a year and a half before me.

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2010 04:11PM LizM wrote: Hi Cindy, Just wanted to stop by and tell you that you have come to the right place for knowledge and support.  This forum was and still is my lifeline.  It will be 5 years in September since I was diagnosed with stage II node positive ILC.IDC breast cancer.  I too found my diagnosis to be worse after my surgery.  I had bi-lateral mastectomies, full auxillery dissection, immediate reconstruction with tissues exanders and now implants, chemo, radiation, oophorectomy and am still on aromatase inhibitors.  Lots of treatment but so far so good.   Didn't use cold caps and haven't heard of too many women in the US using them at least not when I was diagnosed.  They do use them in Europe. My advice would be to not get too ahead of what you are currently going through.  Just take it one step at a time.  Your first step will probably be chemo so I would visit the chemo thread and start reading for tips and advice on all things chemo.  You will probably have radiation but that will be after the chemo so you will have plenty of time to prepare for radiation and at that time you can read the radiation thread and learn everything about going thru that part of your treatment.  There is also an area in the forum for those of us with breast reconstruction and for those diagnosed with stage III so you can speak with those with a similar diagnosis.  Breast cancer is very very scary but there is so much treatment available and over 2 million survivors/thrivers.  We are all hear to help through each step of your journey.

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2011 09:27PM - edited Jan 4, 2011 09:30PM by LizM loving mother,  I just read this thread for the first time.  I am a five year survivor of stage II node positive breast cancer.  I was treated at John Hopkins, NCI Designated Cancer Center and had a wonderful team of breast cancer oncologists.  It is standard practice at Johns Hopkins to have an MRI before surgery to rule out multi-focal disease.  Please ensure you have an MRI before surgery unless you choose a mastectomy, then it is not necessary.  The latest studies show that the sentinal node biopsy is extremely accurate.  I would not worry about that decision at all.  My breast surgical oncologist at Hopkins did the SNB during the surgical procedure while I was under anesthesia.  When one of the two sentinel nodes came back positive, he took out 6 more nodes, which were all negative.  As to the decision of lumpectomy vs mastectomy, that is a very personal decision that only you can make.  My only advice is to folllow your gut.  My gut told me to remove both of my breasts, which is what I did and had immediate reconstruction so that I woke up with the beginning of my new breasts.  I made the decision that was right for me and have not regretted my decision.  You mentioned something about muscle involvement.  You may want to get more information regarding this involvement and if a mastectomy would be better treatment in your case.  If it were me I would get a 2d opinion from a breast cancer specialist at a NCI designated cancer center if at all possible.  You have time to get all the information you need to make the best possible decision.  One more thing to add.  I agree that you do not need to know your ER/PR or her2 status at this stage.  That information is very important after your surgery as it will determine what treatment will work best on your particular breast cancer.   Good luck with your decisions - I know they are not easy to make.
Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed :( loving_mother nwest125

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2011 01:09PM - edited Jan 5, 2011 01:12PM by LizM Loving_mother,  I am assuming the 10% false negative means that in the operating room at first look under the microscope the node looks negative but then when it is sent to the lab for further examination by the pathologist, they find microscopic disease.   That can happen, but when it does, they just go in and take out more nodes or could make the decision not to take out more nodes but you would be involved in that decision process.  The sentinel node biopsy is the way to go now.  No need to take out more than one  node if they are all negative.  A recurrence in the auxilla is very unlikely with today's treatment.  I had one positive sentinel node and one negative sentinel node and also 6 negative auxillery nodes.  I also opted for radiation to the auxilla for added insurance and further risk reduction.
Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed :( loving_mother nwest125

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2008 01:54PM LizM wrote: Looks like a pretty good report. invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) is the most common Grade 1 is the slowest growing Strong estrogen receptor positive is a GOOD thing (means you should respond well to hormone therapy) Strong progesterone positive is also a GOOD thing  (when both ER and PR are positive means an even better response to hormone therapy) Wouldn't worry about the necrosis since it is in the DCIS (noninvasive) component. Her2  2+ is a false positive according to my oncologist FISH is the most reliable and will probably come back as negative.  Most 2+ on IHC staining come back negative on FISH.  It is also unusual to be her2 positive with a grade 1 tumor but is possible.  If her2 positive it means a more aggressive tumor but there is also targeted therapy with herceptin which has changed the prognosis for her2 positive disease.

Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2008 02:21PM LizM wrote: I actually had mixed IDC and ILC in the same tumor.  My pathology report said insitu and infiltrating mammary carcinoma with ductal and lobular features.  My oncologist did not think it was any big deal and said they were both treated the same and prognosis was basically the same.  I consider myself to have had IDLC.  I did some research and although it is not that common, the prognosis seems to be similar to IDC only or ILC only and ILC is sometimes even thought to have a slightly better prognosis than IDC.  The most important factor is if your tumors tested positive for  ER/PR so that you can take hormone therapy.

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2011 01:51PM - edited Jan 11, 2011 01:53PM by LizM Bec9861, I had to go back and look at the t-shirt after the comment and have to say that I don't find the shirt offensive at all.  My breasts did almost kill me and I'm glad they are gone.  We all have to make the decision that is right for us individually (there is no one size fits all) and I have no regrets whatsoever.  I am 5 years out and if I could go back I would do exactly the same thing, bi-lateral mastecomy, reconstruction, chemo, rads, oophorectomy and 5 years of hormonal treatment.  Yes, very aggressive treatment but as my oncologist says, whatever gives you peace of mind.   Good luck with your decisions loving-mom and your surgery - you will be in my prayers.  Keep us posted.

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2009 10:43AM LizM wrote: I believe the standard of care is to remove more nodes if the sentinel node is positive.  My breast surgeon at Johns Hopkins does not think it is necessary to remove two levels of nodes but he does remove the first level, which I believe can have as few as 7 and as many as 15.  I had 8 nodes in the first level removed and one sentinel node was positive.  If all 3 of your nodes were positive I would think he would remove more.  Sometimes for neoadjuvant chemo before surgery they just test the sentinel node to see if cancer is in the nodes and then do chemo before surgery.  However, when they do surgery, they do remove more nodes.  I would definately get a second opinion.

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2009 09:37AM LizM wrote: Hi Luv2sing, I am also surprised the radiologist told you it was breast cancer before the results of the biopsy.  We all know how hard the waiting is and have been exactly where you are now.  What you read on the internet can be quite scary especially when you don't know exactly what you are dealing with.  My advice is to TRY and take it one step at a time.  Don't get too far ahead of yourself.  Just research information on what you know about your own situation as it can become very overwhelming.  With that said, I am an over three year survivor of stage II breast cancer and am doing just fine.  Over 88% of women diagnosed with breast cancer today WILL become long term survivors.  I pray you do not end up having breast cancer but if you do keep coming here because the women on these boards will help you through each step of your journey.  I have been coming here for support since I was diagnosed in September 2005.

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2007 06:58AM LizM wrote: It saddens me to see that doctors and especially breast specialists are still balking at getting MRI's for high risk patients. After my diagnosis of ALH and ADH in Dec 04 I asked my breast surgeon who is the chief of breast surgery at Johns Hopkins if I should have an MRI and he told me no. He did agree to a diagnostic mammogram which I had the next fall which found my breast cancer but I still believe that if I would have had an MRI 8 months earlier my breast cancer would have been found at an earlier stage. When the ultrasound finally picked it up in Sep 05 it was 1.4 cm and final pathology after bi-lateral showed it to be 2.1 cm and in one sentinel node making me stage II. I had very dense breasts and the mammogram was probably never going to pick it up. I will never know if the MRI would have picked up my breast cancer earlier but I suspect it would have and it haunts me to this day.

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2009 10:18AM LizM wrote: I had terrible gas pains while on Arimidex which is one of the reasons I switched to Femara.  I also had an oophorectomy before I started Arimidex so it could have been the ooph.  Anyway, I was eating a lot of raw veggies, especially brocolli.  I have been forced to change my diet.  I had to cut out a lot of brocolli (still each once in a while), nuts, bananas.  I also think part of the problem may have been lasting effects of chemo.   Since your immune system is in your digestive tract I think it is very important to have a healthy gut.  I use prebiotics (digestive enzymes), probiotics (organic yogurt) and fiber (acacia fiber).  I do not have doubling over gas pains anymore.  I do pass quite a bit of gas but that is going to happen when you eat a diet high in fiber.  I also believe it is important to have a bowel movement at least once a day.  One problem I still have is hard stools which might be from the Femara or the calcium I take.  I know this is a lovely topic but an important one nonetheless.

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2011 07:46PM - edited Jan 18, 2011 07:51PM by LizM I hate to say it but I am five years out and I still can't stand going to any of my doctors if they are going to do any labwork or imaging tests or anthing where they could possibly find a recurrence.  I get sick to my stomach.  I think that once you are diagnosed with breast cancer you never trust your body again.  I am always afraid they will find something and I will fall down that slippery slope again.  Sometimes I don't think so much about having breast cancer but when I have a doctors appointment, it all comes rushing back just like I was diagnosed last week.  I also worry a lot more about my grown kids, my DH and my parents.  Every little thing they get I think is something serious also.   I hate this feeling - sometimes I think I need to see a counselor.   Right now I am freaked because I waited to have my annual bloodwork until after Christmas and it just came back last week with my liver enzyme tests minimally elevated.  I know that there are lots of things that can cause elevated LFT's and they have been elevated at least 3 times before and are probably due to medications I am taking but that doesn't help.  I am totally freaked about it and don't want to go back and have then retested because I feel fine, no symptoms and I don't want them to find anything.  Am I crazy??
